/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The commit message would need more context, I feel. Sure, we can read the related bug, but it won't hurt to explain it a bit more here.

The issue is that Nova used to only consider an instance's existing volumes when finding the next available SCSI address when attaching a volume. So if the instance had a config drive in the shape of a SCSI CDROM, its SCSI address would get ignored in the new address calculation, there would be an address collision in the XML, and libvirt would complain.

This tempest test checks that even with a SCSI CDROM, we can attach SCSI volumes to an instance without issue.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Oh! Is the intention to hide this from the containerized services, and only change the location on the host?

If it is, then many of my review comments may be misguided. I started the review thinking the intent was to completely relocate the ceph stuff, even where it's accessed by the services in containers.

Hi Alan,
I'm sorry, we probably didn't give you enough context regarding
this change and the meaning of removing the /etc/ceph dependency.
As you may know, the new role [1] introduces a new Ceph Client role,
which means it's able to render (through jinja templates) some Ceph
variables provided by tht and build the ceph.conf and the specified
keyrings into a defined CephConfigPath (which is defined in the host).
Later in the process, the content of this "tripleo_ceph_config_home"
dir is used by kolla_config to build the Glance/Cinder/Manila/Gnocchi
containers, pushing those files into /etc/ceph (within the container).
For this reason, /etc/ceph is maintained inside the container, but
the path might not be the same in the host.
For the users that tries to see the content present in the resulting
containers nothing change (the experience is still the same since the
files can always be found in /etc/ceph).

Why we need this change?

With ceph-ansible (which executed its client role) we didn't care about
the content of /etc/ceph because it was managed by the same tool but,
with cephadm (and with a different role to configure the ceph clients),
it's important having a way to avoid collisions (e.g. in the hci context
osd and nova compute are collocated and they access the same /etc/ceph
which is managed by different tools that can overwrite these files).
For scale lab reasons, we also tried to avoid inspecting the content of
/etc/ceph before pushing the resulting (rendered) config, and separating
the lifecycle of the content managed by cephadm (or ceph-ansible) and by
tripleo_ceph_client role seems the solution.
There are a few other reasons, but this is basically the context that led
us to avoid using and harcoded /etc/ceph everywhere.
Being that said, it's ok having /etc/ceph hardcoded when the ceph.conf path
is defined in a variable that will be resolved within the container, but we
need to make it customizable when the reference appears in the path used by
the tools used to generate the config files and keyrings.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/758039/59/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_ceph_client/defaults/main.yml#23

doc/source/configuration.rst.message: Kazoo doesn't seem to throw any sort of error if you supply an invalid string for the scheme, and you just get authorization errors on znode operations. I think we should catch this up front and error if an invalid value is supplied.

We need to describe the format of this string as "username:password". It might actually make more sense to have separate config fields for those values and format the credential string ourselves to force the correct format.
I raised a question in the Zuul change about whether we should have user + password here or just an opaque credential.

For auth_data that seems possible, but for the kazoo make_acl function, it seems like the value can't be opaque (e.g. we need to either hash the password (which is not done yet) for digest, or just use the login for sasl (as you suggested previously)).

Also this (not release yet) change: https://github.com/python-zk/kazoo/commit/cd49b3fa01136848c5e6bfafb4c241b9704f249d , seems to imply that GSSAPI mechanism can't be opaque either (e.g. we need to differentiate `service` and `principale`).

I think it is very unlikely that zuul user are connecting to a shared zookeeper service, and perhaps we shouldn't bother with all the auth possibility and we could pick the one we are able to setup and test: the digest sasl. In that situation, the configuration would only need a `username` and `password`.

PS33 moves all the logic to a common module so that we can easily change the data formats.
Let's omit the scheme and only support sasl.  Digest is too weird -- the password is encoded in the ACL.  I don't think I can endorse anyone using that -- password rotation is too hard.
alright, i'll drop the scheme setting

This preconfiguration suggests that this driver doesn't quite match the design of the system. How about, "With this proposal, the source service will be able to either send notifications or use a new client library to directly index the data by bypassing additional middleware."
Done.  Clarified on middleware since it might be confused with wsgi middleware
These services use the OSLO Messaging library.

I started writing inline suggestions and then decided to just provide a suggested wording improvement for the whole section

The following options have been identified for services which don't generate notifications.

Change the service to send notifications using the OSLO messaging libraries.
Create a Searchlight client library which can be used by the service to directly update ElasticSearch. This library will need to stay aligned with its associated Searchlight API plugin to ensure that the data mappings, resource types, and target indices stay in sync.
Create a client library which is similar to option 2 but does not add any additional dependencies.  The library will not have any dependencies and will use http client to directly communicate with ElasticSearch for sending updates (rather than the ElasticSearch python client library).
Option 1 is the recommended option for resiliency. Without it, the source service must take ownership of handling ElasticSearch downtime as well as handling all data consistency checks.

If notifications cannot be sent due to some restrictions on source service, the next best option would be 2 and then 3.

Option 2 and 3 will have the disadvantage of not utilizing the full capabilities of searchlight like zero down time reindexing [0].

[0] Searchlight provides a feature called zero downtime re-indexing where an administrator can on-demand rebuild the indexes from various sources without any noticeable disruption to end users.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/searchlight-specs/specs/mitaka/zero-downtime-reindexing.html

I wanted to share two points about possible ways to implement this.
The first uses a middleware to propagate updates to ES. The middleware can use green threads and minimally affect the Swift request processing. It is then added to the pipeline on every proxy node.
The second one that may be interesting is through this patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/304332/. It exposes the get_items_since() API on the container server, which would allow a process to look through all of the entries in the container database and propagate those updates to ES. It would allow for building a more efficient indexer and is the container_sync approach John referred to during the meeting.

Calling Searchlight from Swift WSGI middleware was used in notification patch but the problem was that response headers in the pipeline didn't have all the fields required for indexing in searchlight, so within the middleware a HEAD request was issued to get the details.  I will document that as an approach here.
This is option 3 POC (no dependency on ES).

i tought you said its not a valid value.

the behavior of this bug imples when pick selected ""
puppet-nova did not render it as ' dhcp_domain="" ' but instead rendered it as ' dhcp_domain= '
those are not equivelent and will have different behaviors.

' dhcp_domain= ' is the same as unset which means the options default of novalocal takes effect.

' dhcp_domain="" ' sets the domain in nova code to "" so when we append it to the hostname its unchanged.

since we are seing overcloud-novacompute-0.novalocal  not overcloud-novacompute-0 in the bug error output
it means that puppet nova is not correctly rendering the empty string.

the empty string is a valid value for dhcp_domain and shoudl be supprted by puppet-nova.
its used when you want to disable nova adding a suffix to the hostnames

(from #openstack-nova today)

The 'add host' and 'remove host' commands accept a host as a positional arguments.

  $ openstack aggregate add host ... <aggregate> <host>
  $ openstack aggregate remove host ... <aggregate> <host>

Yet 'cache image' takes images as optional parameters:

  $ openstack aggregate cache image ... [--image <image>] <aggregate>

Shouldn't they be the same? Namely:

  $ openstack aggregate cache image <aggregate> <image> [<image>...]

the issue here is that caching image support multiple images at once. Having all of those as positional params is really not user-friendly. Add/Remove host does not support modifying multiple hosts at once. I understand your concern, but we need to find consensus here.

> the issue here is that caching image support multiple images at
 > once. Having all of those as positional params is really not
 > user-friendly.

Replied at top-level (tl;dr: I don't think it's an issue)

 > Add/Remove host does not support modifying multiple
 > hosts at once. I understand your concern, but we need to find
 > consensus here.
